Pushed as WIP patch for the reference on production code changes. Working on the UT area. Will push the final working patch soon.

Suggestion: we could use `std::string_view` instead of `const std::string&`. Any issues with that here? The same comment applies everywhere.

FYR: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40127965/how-exactly-is-stdstring-view-faster-than-const-stdstring


It not be allowing due to the existing API signature used in this API implementation? (we cannot convert string_view into string)
to be consistent with all of the other calls, it may be better to just keep it how it is.
Okay, it's not easy to change because many APIs use `const std::string&`, so we can't convert from `std::string_view` to `const std::string&`.

I believe the getDIProperty API has a restriction due to these specified arguments value, correct?

- This API currently expects only the expanded location code, so we should specify this in the API documentation. If there is a need to support unexpanded location codes, we can enhance the API in the future.

- This API won't work in a multi-node system because it currently passes the node number as 0. While this isn't an issue now since we're using expanded location codes, it could become problematic if we decide to support unexpanded location codes in the future.
there's going to need to be a lot of changes to support multiple nodes, so we can handle that all at a later time.
Agreed, it would require significant changes. Recommended to add some notes in the API documentation for future reference.
Added a note.

Please avoid hard-coding the service name. The given location code object could be hosted by PIM, EM, PLDM, or any other application, so we should determine the service name based on the object path and interface name.

Use `DataInterface::getService` API
for consistency, i'd prefer it's just kept how it is.  Also, this will be called for every callout so we can reduce the dbus calls.
ok :)

I believe we don't need to include the return data type in the API documentation. It's sufficient to describe what will be returned in both success and error cases.

something like
```
* @return The DI property value on success or no value on failure
```
other functions were doing it. I'm OK either way.
Done

How about below return description?

```
* @return true if the given location code belongs to DIMM; otherwise, return false.
```
Slightly modified. Avoid the phrase 'belongs to DIMM' as there is a case which the location code is not present in cache but still is a DIMM

The reason for the pure virtual functions is just for the unit tests, where we can use EXPECT_CALL on the MockDataInterface to handle calls that do things we don't have in test, like D-Bus.

Since that is not the case for these functions that deal with the cache and you do want to test these, you can make them non virtual.
Done
Same as mentioned in LN498
Done
Same as mentioned LN510
Done
Remove unwanted new line.
Done
`dimmInfoFetchError` and `DIMMs` to make more generic?
Done
This is just to mimic the pHAL API response for testing. Will remove once the pHAL API is ready.
I think when you are removing this code, you need to remove LN46.
Done

We are violating the API signature; the caller assumes that the dataIface object won't be modified, but we are making changes to it.

I understand that updating all instances in this API call flow would be significant. Therefore, we have two options: either document this exception in the API documentation or change the argument to be non-const in the API flow.
Done
Removed the line itself as part of new changes

We could use `std::to_underlying` without assuming it will be `uint8_t`.

For example:

```
std::to_underlying<openpower::phal::exception::ERR_TYPE>(fruType.error())
```
I agree . But kept it unchanged by thinking std::to_underlying requires adding one more header called utility.And it will work fine until phal error codes less than 256 in numbers

It could be written like LN803/810 and add location code in the trace as well to improve debuggability. 

```
debugData[dramInfoFetchError].emplace_back("Failed reading DI property from VINI Interface");
```
Done
the code guidelines want { } even for single line statements
Done
addAdDIMMDetails?

Suggestion: It could also be written as follows.

```
std::ranges::for_each(src->callouts()->callouts() | std::views::filter(dimmsCallout), addAdDIMMDetails);
```

(I understand you did not prefer `std::views::transform` because you are not transferring the callouts object. Instead, you are extracting DIMM callouts and adding additional details in a separate section, rather than in the callout section.)
Acknowledged
Just suggestion comment. I am fine with either way.
I believe this API collects data and adds it to the provided adSysInfoData. We should update the description to reflect this accurately.
Modified

It's not just getting data; it's also adding it to the `adSysInfoData` argument.

How about renaming it to `addAdDetailsForDIMMsCallout`?
Done
Suggestion: I think we could add a `using` alias for this data type in `pel.hpp` and use it throughout the codebase.
Acknowledged
DIMM?
Acknowledged
Hard coded the value for the time being in order to pass the existing UT cases. Working on the UT area. Will fix this also.
Removed
nit: how about just 'Add'
How about `PEL: Add DIMMs DRAM Manufacturer Info`?
I felt 'DIMMs DRAM' phrase might be redundant. hence slightly modified
nit:  how about:  When a PEL calls out a DIMM FRU.
nit:  I think this needs to be split up into another sentence, I don't quite follow it as one.

+1 and I feel a few statement repeated.

Also, please add why are you adding these details now like describe problem statement in generic for this solution.
Done
Ah you added here. I feel, we could describe the purpose "why" of this commit in beginning.
Please avoid internal terms in the OpenSource project.
Acknowledged
Acknowledged
I think your code now has 'DIMMs Manu...'  now?
Acknowledged

I think we will always use the PHAL API for non-DIMM callouts.

One of the goals of implementing a cache is to avoid the overhead of walking the PHAL device tree or repeated PHAL interactions when the same location code is called out multiple times for different reasons or at different times, right?.

Therefore, I suggest maintaining a cache for all location codes and checking for DIMM-related ones.

For example, we could use something like:

```
std::unordered_map<LocationCode, bool> locationCache;
```

@Matt, any thoughts on this approach? Or would it be better to stick with the PHAL API for non-DIMM cases?

PHAL will always be enabled on a real system. I think just not in CI which is why the compile flags were put in.

I like the map idea.
Yes I also agree the map can reduce the overhead further more. Will try to incorporate
Thanks for accepting.
would have also been fine to put the error into the journal.  it's no more likely to fail than line 905.

+1, or in the caller places with returned unexpected value.

People might sometimes overlook the PEL debug data section.
Added journal trace at the caller.
Please document about the function parameters and returns.
Done

ideally, this would have been a standalone commit, but at this point isn't necessary.

It would be good it add it to the commit message how you're changing this.
+1, My preference would be a separate commit. I am fine either way :)
ok will mention in the commit msg
why did this need to be added?
nit:  the guidelines say to always capitalize acronyms, so about about 'isDIMMCallout'
Acknowledged
Missed adding the location code value here so that in case of multiple DIMM callouts, user could identify for which location code it failed. Will incorporate this also in next patch
Done
I feel `DRAM Manufacturer ID` more readable since the parent key contains `DIMMs`.
Do we have separate manufacturers for DIMM and DRAMs?
It could be. The DI property is primarily intended for DRAM within the DIMM inventory object, so we could have a separate manufacturer ID for the DIMM module.
`DIMMs Additional Info` to make it more generic?
Yes..Modified.
why change this one and the one below?

I think we will enter [here](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-logging/+/72970/4/extensions/openpower-pels/data_interface.cpp#933) for the existing test case since the caller invoke `isDIMM` API always and cache will be empty.
why are you using any_of here and not checking the result? i guess because it stops after find an entry?

> @Ramesh, It seems some typo here , return std::make_pair(hasDIMMInfo, hasDimmInfo); Did you meant 'dimmInfo' instead of 'hasDimmInfo'?

ah my bad, correct `dimmInfo`.

> I feel return value of any_of is less important as I am comparing the fetched JSON object from the UD section with the expected json object.

Hmm ok...
nit:  these are tabs.  if there aren't tabs anywhere else in this file then please convert them to spaces to be consistent.
nit: trailing space
Acknowledged
Addressing the review comments

Modified the variable name to 'listOfDIMMCallouts' just to adhere to the guidelines ,"Acronym should be capitalised". But the older 'dimmsCallouts' seems better. 

@Matt @Ramesh, What's your view on this?

> Modified the variable name to 'listOfDIMMCallouts' 
Ok...

> But the older 'dimmsCallouts' seems better.
Agree, I would prefer dimmsCallouts, but "Acronym should be capitalized" makes sense to me. If the CI doesn't throw any errors, then I would go with DIMMsCallouts.
the faulty DRAMs packaged within the DIMM module? the applies to the commit message header since we are adding the DRAM manufacturer info, not the DIMM one.
the DRAM manufacturer ID?
a new clang format went in, so if you just rebase on master and run format-code.sh again it'll fix it up.

I haven't reviewed it yet. I'll wait for the CI fix.

(I've just responded to some of the open comments.)
A few minor suggestions you could address in your CI fix patch if you agree with them.

May be I missed this in the previous patch..

why is it required here? Please include in the .cpp file based on the needs.

I thought you were planning to use unordered_map as discussed in another comment.

Are you planning to fix this separately?
additional?
